item.title: Three years of James Webb Telescope in 10 stunning pictures - India Today
item.description:
Three Years of James Webb Telescope in 10 Stunning Images

Publication Date: December 2024 | Source: India Today

This article showcases ten exceptional images captured by the James Webb Telescope over the past three years, highlighting its technological advancements and its contributions to our understanding of the universe.

  • Webb's view of ice giant Uranus, showcasing its dynamic features.
  • The breathtaking Pillars of Creation, revealing newly formed stars.
  • Visualization of the dwarf galaxy Wolf-Lundmark-Melotte, filled with countless stars.
  • Discovery of a protostar hidden in the hourglass shape of light.
  • Galaxies merging with visible star-forming regions connecting them.
  • Image of NGC 7469, a galaxy bursting with new stars.
  • Southern Ring planetary nebula observed in mid-infrared.
“Webb’s infrared vision can peer through dust to observe cosmic phenomena like never before.”

The James Webb Telescope continues to redefine our perspective of the cosmos, revealing exquisite details and contributing significantly to astronomical discoveries.

item.title: Yearly round-up: The biggest science stories of 2024 - Deccan Herald
item.description:
Yearly round-up: The biggest science stories of 2024

Published on 26 December 2024 by Deccan Herald

As humanity completed another revolution around the Sun, science threw up some fascinating findings this year. Here’s a look at some of the biggest stories in science for 2024.

  • The hottest year on record: 2024 has been declared the hottest year since records began in 1850, with severe heatwaves across the globe.
  • HIV prevention drug shows immense promise: The FDA-approved drug lenacapavir demonstrated 96%-100% success rates in two trials.
  • In search of extraterrestrial life: NASA's Clipper mission targets Jupiter's moon Europa for signs of life.
  • A perfect storm: The northern lights were visible far beyond their typical range due to solar activity.
  • Mapping a fruit fly's brain: Researchers mapped a fruit fly's brain containing over 140,000 neurons.
  • Detecting Alzheimer's: A new blood test for Alzheimer's showed 88%-92% accuracy, simplifying detection.
  • Human-Neanderthal breeding timeline: Interbreeding between humans and Neanderthals determined to have occurred around 50,500 to 43,500 years ago.
  • Gene editing with a dash of AI: CRISPR technology is enhanced with AI, resulting in a new gene editing tool.
  • New moons around old planets: Three new moons were discovered orbiting Uranus and Neptune.
  • Oldest reptile skin: The oldest known fossilized reptile skin was found, dated over 300 million years ago.

2024 was a landmark year for scientific discoveries, setting the stage for future advancements.

item.title: Equal to a trillion hydrogen bombs: Is the Sun readying for a violent super explosion? - India Today
item.description:
Equal to a trillion hydrogen bombs: Is the Sun readying for a violent super explosion?

Published On: Dec 26, 2024 Source: India Today

An international team of researchers has discovered that sun-like stars, including our own Sun, can produce enormous radiation outbursts known as superflares approximately every hundred years. This is a significant increase compared to prior estimations of their frequency.

  • Superflares release energy levels surpassing a trillion hydrogen bombs.
  • Researchers analyzed data from NASA's Kepler space telescope, identifying 2,889 superflares across 2,527 stars.
  • The occurrence rate of these superflares is substantially higher than previously thought.
  • Evidence from tree rings and glacial ice indicates past extreme solar activities.
  • The study emphasizes the necessity of monitoring sun-like stars for better frequency estimation of superflares.
“The implications for Earth are significant; a superflare could pose even greater risks to modern infrastructure and satellites.” - Dr. Valeriy Vasilyev

Monitoring methods will improve with ESA’s upcoming space probe Vigil, set to enhance monitoring capabilities starting in 2031.

item.title: Asteroid Alert! Airplane-sized Giant Space Rock Set For Close Encounter With Earth On Dec 28, NASA Issues Warn - Times Now
item.description:
Asteroid Alert! Airplane-sized Giant Space Rock Set For Close Encounter With Earth On Dec 28

Date: December 28, 2024 | Source: NASA

This week, NASA confirmed that an 80-foot asteroid named 2024 YQ2 will safely pass by Earth on December 28, 2024, at a speed of 58,360 km/h.

  • Asteroid 2024 YQ2 will fly by at a distance of 1,030,000 km, over twice the distance between the Earth and the Moon.
  • Despite its size, 2024 YQ2 is not a threat to Earth and is classified as a Near-Earth Object (NEO).
  • NASA is monitoring near-Earth asteroids to better understand our solar system and refine planetary defense strategies.
  • The NEO Surveyor mission, aimed at improving detection of hazardous asteroids, is set to launch in 2028.
“For an asteroid to be considered a Potentially Hazardous Object, it must be larger than 150 meters and come within 7.5 million kilometers of Earth.”

NASA's ongoing efforts to monitor and study asteroids like 2024 YQ2 underscore the importance of planetary defense and preparedness for potential future threats.

item.title: Quiz | Easy like Sunday morning: What has science done for us in 2024? - The Hindu
item.description:
Quiz | Easy like Sunday morning: What has science done for us in 2024?

Published: December 26, 2024 09:03 am IST

This article presents a quiz highlighting key scientific achievements and discoveries from 2024. It includes intriguing questions that explore topics ranging from space exploration to animal behavior.

  • 1. 'Odysseus' became the first commercial vehicle to land on the moon, carrying historic information.
  • 2. New species named E.akayima discovered in the Caribbean.
  • 3. Three new moons were added to the known list of satellites in our Solar System.
  • 4. Mosquitoes dubbed 'World’s deadliest animal' with significant engineered interventions.
  • 5. University of Maine's 'Factory of the Future' debuted a massive 3D printer.
  • 6. 'Retrowalking' found beneficial for spinal health.
  • 7. Elephants communicate with 469 distinct calls.
  • 8. X-59 QueSST aims to achieve supersonic flight without sonic boom disruptions.
  • 9. Hot baths help combat Chytrid disease affecting frogs.
  • 10. Artemis 2 is set to take humans back to the Moon.
“Elephants call each other by specific names.”

The quiz invites readers to reflect on the fascinating advancements in science and encourages engagement with scientific exploration.

item.title: "That’s a super siiiick photo!!" — Internet reacts to NASA posting picture of a star cluster in space that looks like a Christmas tree - Sportskeeda
item.description:
Internet's Enthusiastic Reaction to NASA's Festive Star Cluster Photo

Publication Date: December 24, 2024

Source: Sportskeeda

NASA and ESA recently released a stunning photo of the 'Christmas Tree Cluster,' NGC 2264, which is about 2300 light years away from Earth. This cosmic image has sparked excitement on social media platforms.

  • The gas in the surrounding nebula is shown in green, enhancing the Christmas tree resemblance.
  • Users on X (formerly Twitter) reacted with enthusiasm, sharing poetic thoughts and celebrating the beauty of the cosmos.
  • Notable comments included reflections on cosmic artistry and profound connections to the universe.
  • The photo highlights NASA's ongoing efforts in cosmic exploration and public engagement.
"That’s a super siiiick photo!! 💚💚💚 very Christmas like!!" - User on X
"The beauty of creation is truly limitless. A cosmic Christmas tree thousands of light-years away reminds us how vast and wondrous the universe is." - Another user

Overall, the festive cosmic imagery has inspired awe and connection among viewers, celebrating both the holiday season and the wonders of space.

item.title: US News Today Live Updates on December 26, 2024 : Donald Trump’s Border Czar Tom Homan calls for $86 billion to launch mass deportations | Today News - Mint
item.description:
US News Today Live Updates on December 26, 2024: Tom Homan Calls for $86 Billion for Mass Deportations

Date: 26 Dec, 2024 Source: LiveMint

Tom Homan, the incoming Border Czar, has proposed a significant funding request to Congress for mass deportations, arguing for its importance to national security.

  • Homan estimates that $86 billion will be necessary to implement the mass deportation plan.
  • The initiative is framed as critical for national security and expected to yield long-term financial benefits.
“This initiative is critical for national security,” said Homan, emphasizing the financial benefits.

This plan is part of ongoing discussions regarding immigration and border security policies under the Trump administration.

item.title: US News Today Live Updates on December 26, 2024 : How did NASA astronauts get Christmas decorations in space? Social media wants answers | Today News - Mint
item.description:
US News Today Live Updates on December 26, 2024: How did NASA astronauts get Christmas decorations in space? Social media wants answers

Published on: 26 Dec, 2024 by LiveMint

NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Sunita Williams brought Christmas cheer to the International Space Station (ISS), raising questions on social media regarding the logistics of getting festive decorations into space.

  • Astronauts Butch Wilmore and Sunita Williams brought Christmas cheer to the ISS, donning Santa hats despite being stranded in orbit since June. Social media buzzed with playful questions about how festive decorations made it on their originally short mission, sparking intrigue about space logistics.
“In today’s dynamic landscape, staying updated on the latest developments across the United States is essential,” the report states.

This event highlights the unique blend of human experience and space exploration, reminding us of the personal connections that endure even in the most challenging environments.

item.title: NASA’s cosmic ‘Wreath’ and ‘Christmas Tree’ shed light on stellar birth and evolution - News9 LIVE
item.description:
NASA’s cosmic ‘Wreath’ and ‘Christmas Tree’ shed light on stellar birth and evolution

Date: December 2024

Source: Science News

New Delhi: NASA has revealed breathtaking images of two star clusters, NGC 602 and NGC 2264, resembling festive decorations. These clusters allow astronomers to observe stellar birth in contrasting cosmic environments.

  • The images from NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory and James Webb Space Telescope show surrounding gas and dust formations.
  • NGC 602, located 200,000 light-years away in the Small Magellanic Cloud, displays young stars in an ionised gas region.
  • NGC 2264 is known as the “Christmas Tree Cluster” and is about 2,500 light-years away, showcasing a conical shape resembling a Christmas tree.
  • The data offers insights into star formation and the life cycle of stars.
“These cosmic images paint how beautiful and intricate the process of star formation is.”

NASA's continuous exploration extends our knowledge of the universe's mysteries, shedding light on the processes of star formation and evolution.

item.title: NASA Parker Solar Probe Makes Closest-Ever Approach to the Sun, Becomes Fastest Object Built by Humans - Gadgets 360
item.description:
NASA’s Parker Solar Probe Makes Its Closest-Ever Flyby of the Sun

Publication Date: December 25, 2023 Source: Gadgets 360

The Parker Solar Probe has completed its closest-ever flyby of the Sun, reaching a distance of approximately 6.1 million kilometers, gathering crucial data about the solar environment.

  • First man-made object to approach this close to the Sun.
  • During the flyby, it achieved a speed of 692,000 km/h, breaking its previous speed record.
  • Communication with the probe was temporarily lost, with reconnection expected by December 27.
  • This was the 22nd flyby of the Sun, with four more planned for 2025.
  • The probe helps scientists understand solar phenomena like coronal mass ejections and their impact on Earth.
“The corona reaches temperatures exceeding 1.1 million degrees Celsius at a certain distance from the Sun.”

This milestone enhances NASA's ability to study solar activity and its implications for Earth, offering insights into solar storms that can affect technology and infrastructure.

item.title: Asteroid alert! Giant asteroid narrowly misses Earth this Christmas - News9 LIVE
item.description:
Giant Asteroid 2024 YP Narrowly Misses Earth This Christmas

Publication Date: December 19, 2024 | Source: Science News

This Christmas, the asteroid NEO 2024 YP will pass Earth at a dangerously close distance, raising concerns among scientists as it moves at high speed.

  • The asteroid 2024 YP will fly past Earth at a distance of approximately 994,398 km on Christmas Day, 2024.
  • Discovered on December 19, 2024, it belongs to the Apollo group of asteroids.
  • 2024 YP is considered a potentially hazardous object, but no collision threat is currently identified.
  • The asteroid has a low absolute magnitude of 27.085, indicating its small size.
  • Orbital characteristics show it takes about 1.33 Earth years to complete an orbit around the Sun.
  • Future approaches are anticipated, with the next close encounter predicted in April 2033.
“This Christmas flyby is a good wake-up call for NEO observation and planetary defence measures.”

The close approach of asteroid 2024 YP highlights the importance of planetary defense efforts and the need for ongoing observation of near-Earth objects.

item.title: NASA-ISRO NISAR satellite unlocks lesser-known mystery of Earth - The Times of India
item.description:
NASA-ISRO NISAR Satellite Unlocks Earth's Secrets

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Times of India

NASA and ISRO's joint NISAR satellite is shedding light on previously uncharted environmental phenomena, enhancing our understanding of Earth's dynamic systems.

  • The satellite integrates advanced radar technologies to monitor land surface changes and natural disasters.
  • NISAR aims to study soil moisture, forest biomass, and ice sheet dynamics.
  • Collaboration emphasizes global partnerships for advancing Earth observation capabilities.
"The NISAR satellite is expected to transform how we view our planet and its ecological changes over time," said a NASA spokesperson.

This groundbreaking collaboration between NASA and ISRO represents a significant leap in satellite technology and Earth science.

item.title: Science for all Scientists find bacteria living on fish brains - The Hindu
item.description:
Scientists Discover Bacteria Living on Fish Brains

Published: December 25, 2024 12:05 pm IST

This article discusses a groundbreaking study that reveals bacteria can not only access fish brains but also thrive there, challenging the long-held belief that the brain is a sterile environment.

  • Research conducted by scientists at the University of New Mexico found living bacteria in the olfactory bulbs and other brain regions of salmon and trout.
  • Unique adaptations of these microbes allow them to cross the blood-brain barrier.
  • The study suggests that the brain's microbial community is shaped by early colonization and ongoing interactions with other bodily systems.
  • Visual evidence shows a bacterium mid-transit across the blood-brain barrier.
  • The findings raise questions about the potential presence and role of bacteria in human brains as well.
“If bacteria can thrive on fish brains, it’s possible they may do so on human brains as well.”

This study signifies a paradigm shift in our understanding of neural environments, indicating a more complex interaction between the brain and microorganisms than previously thought.

item.title: Christmas in space mystery: Astronauts’ festive photo sparks gravity-defying questions - 'Are they in fil - The Times of India
item.description:
Christmas in space mystery: Astronauts’ festive photo sparks gravity-defying questions - 'Are they in film studio?'

Publication Date: [Insert Date] Source: [Insert Source]

This article discusses a recent festive photo taken by astronauts that has raised questions about the authenticity of their surroundings and whether they might be in a film studio.

  • The astronauts shared a photo while celebrating Christmas.
  • The image prompted viewers to question the nature of their environment.
  • Speculations about the use of a film studio have emerged.
“Are they really in space or is this staged?”

The festive image has led to a blend of excitement and skepticism regarding space missions and the experiences of astronauts during holidays.

item.title: How astronauts stuck in space end up with Santa hats for Christmas? Internet flooded with conspiracy theo - The Times of India
item.description:
How astronauts stuck in space end up with Santa hats for Christmas? Internet flooded with conspiracy theories; Nasa responds

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Not specified

This article examines how astronauts celebrate Christmas in space, including the emergence of conspiracy theories related to festive traditions like wearing Santa hats. NASA's responses to these theories provide insight into the realities of holiday celebrations aboard the International Space Station.

  • Astronauts have unique Christmas celebrations in space.
  • Conspiracy theories surrounding NASA's holiday traditions have gained traction online.
  • The significance of maintaining morale and festive spirit in the isolated environment of space is highlighted.
  • NASA addresses and debunks various myths regarding space celebrations.
“Celebrating in space is all about keeping spirits high!” - NASAA representative.

In conclusion, while astronauts may not have the traditional Christmas we know, their adaptations and celebrations highlight human resilience and creativity in the face of extraordinary conditions.

item.title: NASA's Parker Solar Probe makes closest approach to sun - China.org.cn
item.description:
NASA's Parker Solar Probe Makes Historic Closest Approach to the Sun

Date: December 25, 2024 Source: Xinhua

The Parker Solar Probe has made its closest approach to the sun, setting a new record for proximity to our star.

  • The spacecraft is expected to pass within 3.8 million miles (6.1 million kilometers) of the sun's surface.
  • This distance is over seven times closer than any previous missions.
  • Since its launch in 2018, Parker has completed 21 solar flybys, inching closer each time.
  • The mission aims to enhance our understanding of solar wind origins and its impact on Earth.
“The mission aims to collect measurements and images to expand human knowledge of the origin and evolution of solar wind.”

This achievement is crucial for understanding solar dynamics and changing space weather environments that influence technology and life on Earth.

item.title: Earth’s magnetic North Pole is shifting! Here's how it'll change the GPS too - The Times of India
item.description:
Earth’s magnetic North Pole is shifting! Here's how it'll change the GPS too

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: Times of India

An exploration into the recent shifting of Earth’s magnetic North Pole and its implications for GPS technology.

  • The magnetic North Pole has been moving at an accelerating rate.
  • This shift is expected to affect navigation systems globally, including GPS.
  • Updates to magnetic models are necessary to prevent navigational errors.
  • Researchers are monitoring the shift closely to provide necessary updates.
“Understanding the movement of the magnetic North Pole is crucial for accurate navigation.”

The ongoing changes in Earth’s magnetic field require continuous research and adaptation in technology to ensure navigation systems remain accurate and reliable.
